newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan environmental agency cautious on China dam.
newsitem.headline: Japan environmental agency cautious on China dam.

text.p: Japan's Environment Agency on Wednesday urged caution in providing trade insurance and loans to China's huge dam project on the Yangtze river because of environmental fears and human rights concerns.

"The decision to grant loans and trade guarantees should take into account concerns for the possible effect on the environment and the problem of resettling the one million people who will be displaced by the dam construction," said Masami Tsuji, an official of the Environment Agency's Office for Overseas Environmental Cooperation.
"The Trade Ministry has already sent an evaluation team to the construction area...but we would like them to further consider the environmental and human rights issues," Tsuji said.
It is not known what, if any, effect the agency's concerns will have on policy.

Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced on Tuesday that it would provide trade insurance alongside loans from the Export-Import Bank of Japan for the ambitious project to construct the world's largest dam in Hubei Province, central China.

Also, a consortium of Japanese companies planned on Wednesday to bid for contracts worth 50 billion yen ($442 million) to 70 billion yen ($619 million) to supply power generation equipment for the dam.

The dam will flood an area of 600-square km (230-square miles) in one of China's most picturesque spots and has drawn heavy fire from overseas environmental and human rights groups, which fear damage to the river ecology and are concerned over the resettlement of 1.2 million local residents.
Estimates of the project's total cost have ranged from $24 billion to $30 billion. ($1=113 yen)
